definitions.definition: To take illegally , or without the owner 's permission , something owned by someone else without intending to return it.
examples: Three irreplaceable paintings were stolen from the gallery.
The problem is the two bicycles stolen from us.
They stole all my money (from me).

definitions.definition: To appropriate without giving credit or acknowledgement.
examples: They stole my idea for a biodegradable, disposable garbage de-odorizer.
definitions.label_groups: transitive , of ideas, words, music, a look, credit, etc.

definitions.definition: To get or effect surreptitiously or artfully .
examples: He stole glances at the pretty woman across the street.

definitions.definition: To acquire at a low price.
examples: He stole the car for two thousand less than its book value.
He got that car for two grand under book? Wow, he stole that thing!

definitions.definition: To draw attention unexpectedly in (an entertainment), especially by being the outstanding performer. Usually used in the phrase steal the show .

examples: He stole across the room, trying not to wake her.

definitions.definition: To advance safely to (another base) during the delivery of a pitch, without the aid of a hit, walk, passed ball, wild pitch, or defensive indifference.
To borrow for a short moment.
To take or retell someone else’s joke; to use a clever phrase or expression from someone else in one's own speaking or writing.

main_definition: ( transitive ) To take illegally , or without the owner 's permission , something owned by someone else without intending to return it.
secondary_definitions: ( transitive , of ideas, words, music, a look, credit, etc. ) To appropriate without giving credit or acknowledgement.
( transitive ) To get or effect surreptitiously or artfully .
( transitive , informal , figurative ) To acquire at a low price.
( transitive ) To draw attention unexpectedly in (an entertainment), especially by being the outstanding performer. Usually used in the phrase steal the show .
( intransitive ) To move silently or secretly .
( transitive , baseball ) To advance safely to (another base) during the delivery of a pitch, without the aid of a hit, walk, passed ball, wild pitch, or defensive indifference.
( informal , transitive , hyperbolic ) To borrow for a short moment.
( informal , transitive , humorous ) To take or retell someone else’s joke; to use a clever phrase or expression from someone else in one's own speaking or writing.
